tossups.question: These people may have banged their spears on their shields during assemblies called gairethinx. Officials of this people given martial and civil authority over cities and their surrounding territories were called gastaldi, who ranked higher than the the arimannus warrior class. The modern meaning of the title “duke” from the Latin dux developed from regional leaders of this people, who gained enormous power during a period called the (*) “Rule of the Dukes”. A state ruled by this people was founded by Zotto in Beneventum, which outlasted their kingdom to the north by 300 years. The depopulation caused by the long Gothic Wars allowed this people to swiftly defeat the Byzantines and established a kingdom under Alboin ruled from the city of Pavia. For 10 points, name this Germanic people which invaded Italy in the 6th century, named for their distinctive facial hair.

Jongsoo Lee has argued that seeming changes in authorship within poems in this language actually reflect different roles adopted by the multiple singers performing them. The vocable “ohuaya” is common in poetry written in this language. The syllables “ti”, ”to”, “co”, and “qui” were used by early transcribers of poems in this language as a means of notating drum accompaniment. John Bierhorst translated two poetry collections in this language into English, one of which he controversially analogized to the ghost dance. It’s not Old English, but the use of two related words to evoke a single concept in this language, such as (*) “the flower, the song” for “poetry”, is now called difrasismo. In an attempt to elevate the reputation of Texcoco, colonial-era historians attributed many poems that were likely composed by multiple anonymous authors in this language to Nezahualcoyotl (nay-sah-wahl-COE-yodel). For 10 points, what is this language spoken by the Aztecs?

Richard O’Connor has argued that the use of “flow management” in the production of this commodity is what allowed ethnic groups from the north of one region to dominate their southern neighbors. The Kingdom of Lan Na was named for its production of this commodity. Controlling the Ledwin region and its production of this commodity facilitated the rise to power of the Bamar people. An area known for producing this commodity has been called an “Eighth Wonder of the World” for the extensive (*) land modifications made in the Ifugao region. The production of this foodstuff was called the “most convenient and typical means of concentrating population” for states in Zomia by James C. Scott. For 10 points, what is this crop, a staple crop in Southeast Asia usually grown in paddies?

This president’s Secretary of the Navy ordered the construction of four steel protected cruisers collectively known as the “ABCD Ships”. While a young lawyer, this politician represented Elizabeth Jennings Graham in a case which desegregated New York’s streetcar system. This president once served as Quartermaster General of the New York Militia during the Civil War, and one act passed during this president’s term built on the Page Act and was passed two years after the Angell Treaty. A congressional recess allowed (*) Rutherford Hayes to fire this politician from his position as Collector at the Port Authority of New York. During his presidency, the Chinese Exclusion Act and the Pendleton Civil Service Act were passed. This former protege of Roscoe Conkling became president after Charles Guiteau assassinated his predecessor. For 10 points, name this Republican president who succeeded James A. Garfield.

Descriptive answer acceptable Aided by Motiejus Valančius, people called knygnešiai [knig-nesh-”eye”] defied a policy of this kind in Lithuania. A partial repeal of a policy of this kind led to the much-maligned use of the Yaryzhka system. Prositva was a business opened after the repeal of one of these policies. Part of the Korenizatsiya process was a repeal of this kind of policy in education. Along with restricting theater, the (*) Ems decree expanded on policies of this kind implemented in the secret Valuev Circular. During the Russian Empire, the Flying University was an underground group that defied this kind of policy. Illiteracy dramatically increased after this kind of policy was implemented in Congress Poland after the November Uprising. Several Tsars of Russia implemented this kind of policy in “Little Russia” while promoting the use and teaching of Russian. For 10 points, identify this kind of policy designed to curb Ukrainian nationalism and culture during the 19th century.
tossups.answer: language ban (accept any answer involving restricting or banning Ukrainian, Lithuanian, Polish, Romanian)

tossups.question: Descriptive answer acceptable While leading a military campaign against supporters of this cause, Raymond “Turk” Westerling summarily executed suspected supporters. After fighting in the Boer War, Ernest Dekker became an ardent advocate for this cause and founded the IP, a party for its mixed-race supporters. A violent period between supporters and opponents of this cause is named for the local word for “get ready”. A declaration supporting this cause was delivered by the founder of the (*) INP on August 17 after they were kidnapped by young supporters. Supporters of this cause called pemuda killed thousands of people during Bersiap, including Europeans, Ambonese, Mandonese, and Chinese people along with native Rajas and Sultans. Mohammed Hatta signed a declaration supporting this cause two days after Japan surrendered in World War II, who had invaded the country after declaring war on the Netherlands. For 10 points, identify this successful cause led by Suharto, which ended the colony called the Dutch East Indies.
tossups.answer: Indonesian independence (accept answers that describe the decolonization or removal of Dutch power or government from Indonesia)

tossups.question: According to legend, while besieging a city that had revolted against the rule of his son, Abu Karab was converted to this religion by holy men from that city treating him for an illness. During one battle, Nuaym ibn Masud manipulated a tribe following this religion to not proceed with their deception as planned, resulting in the collapse of the other side’s forces. A possible sign of the conversion to this non-native religion is the growth in the use of the word Rahman in Sabaean inscriptions from the (*) Ḥimyarite Kingdom. A ruler who followed this religion attacked the Christians of Najrān and killed himself by walking into the sea; that ruler was Dhu Nuwas. The Banu Nadir and Banu Qurayza were among the tribes following this religion Muhammad encountered in Medina. For 10 points, identify this religion, which lost prominence in the Arabian Peninsula with the advent of a fellow Abrahamic faith, Islam.

A prince of a state in this modern country was captured while hiding in a haystack after his prominent teeth were recognized; that prince was of the Villehardouin family, who Steve Runciman notes unusually did not replace local priests while ruling this modern country. It’s not Romania, but a state in this modern country used a law code called the Assizes of Romania. After they were dismissed without pay, the Catalan Company rose in rebellion and overthrew Walter V of Brienne, a ruler of a state in this modern country.  Though virtually independent, vassals states in the western end of the (*) Latin Empire were in this country. Before moving to Malta, the Knights Hospitaller defended an island in this modern country against a massive army led by Suleiman the Magnificent during a seven month siege. For 10 points, name this modern country where crusader states like the Principality of Achaea and Duchy of Naxos were founded after the Fourth Crusade.

The Xīqīng Gǔjiàn [shee-ching goo-chyen] is a catalogue of the Qiánlóng Emperor’s collection of artifacts made of this material. According to The Records of the Grand Historian, Qín Shĭ Huáng sought nine objects of this material created by Yǔ the Great, which were revered as symbols of kingly authority. Many massive heads made of this material have been found at the site of Sānxīngduī in Sìchuān. Zoomorphic designs called tāotìe feature on many artworks made from this material. Gōng, jué, and zūn were various sizes of (*) vessels made of this material for pouring rice wine. The largest known object made of this material is a ceremonial cauldron known as the Hòumǔwù Dǐng. The tomb of the Marquis Yĭ of Zēng contained a set of 65 bells made of this material. For 10 points, name this material commonly used in Shāng and Zhōu art, an alloy of copper and tin.

Description acceptable Kenneth Jackson identified that this process caused differences in the etymologies of river names in four different areas. The "apartheid" theory attempts to explain the high level of genetic influence of this process because participants created unequal social structures. An account of this process lists several Bretwaldas, powerful men that may have been the top of a social elite created by this process. This process' displacement of native languages may have been encouraged by the uneven value of (*) wergild granted before the law. The writer Gildas' account of this process influenced later characterizations of it as a violent confrontation between its participants and the remnants of Roman aristocracy. The conversion of the people who had partaken in this process to Christianity is recounted in a history by the Most Venerable Bede. For 10 points, identify this process that came after Roman retreat from the central island, which created the kingdoms in the Heptarchy.
tossups.answer: the Anglo-Saxon settlement of Britain (accept any answer involving the spread of Anglo-Saxon culture or people, or the Anglo-Saxons invading Britain)

tossups.question: Sharon R. Steadman has hypothesized that a cave at an archaeological site in this modern country was used to project the voice of a god, reinforced by that site being the origin of a religious tradition according to Karanga folklore. A culture named for a site in this country overtook the Zhizo culture in economic and political power. Shadreck Chirikure has argued that differences in ceramics and wall-construction refute the long-held assumption that the Butua Kingdom, centered in this country, grew out of the previous dominant culture in the region. This modern country contains the type site of Leopard’s Kopje, which names the material culture of the (*) Mapungubwe Kingdom. An archaeological site in this modern country is famous for its sculptures of fishing eagles carved from soapstone. For 10 points, name this modern African country which takes its name from a “Great” archaeological site.

92 men were killed by mines and friendly fire in an invasion of an abandoned island in this state in Operation Cottage. The Battle of the Pips took place off the coast of this state, where US ships fired based on radar signals now believed to have been groups of petrels on the ocean’s surface. In its first military action, the submarine USS Growler single-handedly routed three enemy warships near this state. The Disney film Victory Through Air Power, based on a book of the same name, rejected the strategic potential of this state as argued in its source material. The US gained important information on the enemy’s (*) plane designs after one of them crashed on this state’s Akutan Island after bombing Dutch Harbor. A propaganda poster depicting a rat and a trap on a map of this state called it a “death-trap” for the Japanese. The only American soil seized during WWII was in, for 10 points, what state whose Kiska and Attu Islands were retaken from the Japanese in the Aleutian Islands Campaign?

Cylindrical stone carvings found exclusively near the necks of women in graves of this culture have been interpreted as amulets pertaining to marriage. The deities of this culture are often shown near pipal (“people”) trees, such as on an artifact which shows a god in a pipal being offered a ram and perhaps a human head. Massimo Vidale has argued that a famous sculpture supposedly of this culture shows greater similarity with statues from Gonur and Mundigak. The symbolic importance of water to this culture is suggested through the commonality of (*) bathing platforms and sophisticated drainage systems in its urban centers. An artifact created by this culture depicts a seated figure with buffalo horns and surrounded by an elephant, a buffalo, a rhino, and a tiger, leading it to be called the “Pashupati seal”. For 10 points, identify this Bronze Age culture, whose iconography at sites like Lothal and Mohenjo-Daro has been largely interpreted through later South Asian traditions.

John Parracida was the son of a ruler of this name who killed King Albert I. A ruler of this name often called “king korridge” was briefly a pretender to the Polish throne after marrying Elizabeth Richeza. A ruler of this name had his plot to inherit from his father in-law Charles IV ruined by suddenly dying at age 25. The “Great Interregnum” was ended by the election of a ruler of this name as King of the Romans. A ruler of this name, nicknamed “The Founder”, issued a document that dubiously describes rights granted to (*) Noricum by Julius Caesar and Nero. A ruler of this name greatly increased his territories after he defeated Ottokar II at the Battle of Marchfeld. The second ruler of this name built an elaborate cabinet of curiosities in Prague Castle and sponsored his namesake style of mannerism. In response to emperor Charles IV in Prague, a ruler of this name founded The University of Vienna and forged the Privligium Manius to elevate his family to the title of Archduke. For 10 points, identify this name shared by the first Habsburg Duke and Archdukes of Austria.

Historian Alexandr Osipian argues that the “Flos historiarum terre orientis”, written by a vassal of this state named Hayton, was intended as propaganda to portray it positively to western Christian readers. A ruler of this state printed the Muslim confession of faith, his Buddhist name of Rinchindorj, and Chinese characters after he blatantly copied the system of Chinese jiāochāo paper money. Ilga Noyan founded a family of advisors to this state, which would be succeeded by the (*) Jalayirid dynasty after its collapse. The last ruler of this state, Abu Sa’id, may have died of the Black Death. The founder of this state dismantled Alamut Castle after the surrender of the Assassins, and two years later his soldiers dragged Al-Musta’sim in a carpet during the Sack of Baghdad. For 10 points, name this Mongol state founded by Hulagu Khan in the Middle East.
tossups.answer: Ilkhanate (prompt on “Mongolian Empire”; prompt on “Armenia” or “Cilicia” and ask “what larger state were they vassals of”)

tossups.question: In an episode of an early 2000’s Flash animated series named after him, this man is shown trying to pick up women in a bar in Calcutta with Mahatma Gandhi. In The Grim Adventures of Billy and Mandy, when Grim becomes friends with Mindy, Billy invites this man to be his friend, who later builds a house for Mandy in the mall. As one of “History’s Greatest Villains” in an episode of Futurama, an axe-wielding “evil” version of this man wrecks Kif’s holo-shed simulation. This man is depicted with devil horns and his death is glorified in the artwork of (*) The Founders in Bioshock Infinite. In another Futurama appearance, a resident of the Hal Institute for Criminally Insane Robots built to impersonate this man claims to have been born in 200 log cabins. General critical acclaim and an Oscar followed Daniel Day-Lewis’ portrayal of this man in a 2012 film. For 10 points, who is this man, the President of the US during the Civil War?

This people called its land Kengir, or “land of the noble lords”. Statues of the deities of this people were taken from their sacred spaces to legitimate festivals and oaths, and they often traveled to other cities. A ruler of this people may have run 100 miles and back in a day to officiate a ceremony in a different state, and in one document, claimed that “like a noble ass”, his running pleased the gods. Rulers of this people were the [emphasize] first to prefix their names with an unpronounced symbol called dingir to ascribe themselves divinity, as done by King (*) Shulgi. A “big man”, or lugal, named Meskalamdug was buried in the “Royal Cemetery” of one of the cities of this people. Lives of many thousands of years characterize the rulers of this people prior to a flood according to their namesake “king list”. For 10 points, identify this people, whose kings ruled cities like Eridu and Uruk.

Historian Marc Bloch noted that peasants in St. Albans and Peterborough who refused to use these devices were beaten, jailed, and even executed. The earliest example of a complex type of these devices was found at Nendrum Monastery on Mahee Island in Ireland. During the medieval period, hammers used along with these devices allowed for the fulling of cloth by only one person instead of the slaves needed during Roman times. Geoffrey of Clairvaux requested the construction of Clairvaux II because it was a better place to (*) build one of these structures; soon after, the Cistercines began purchasing these structures across Western Europe to stay economically self-sufficient. During the Middle Ages, the more efficient “overshot” kind of this structure replaced the simpler “undershot” kind developed in Egypt and China. Peasants paid for their obligation to use one of these structures owned by their Lord with a portion of the processed product. For 10 points, name these devices built on rivers that powered medieval industry and grinded grain.
tossups.answer: watermills (accept windmills, tidal mills, water turbines or water wheels)

tossups.question: John A. Benson cheated the government out of hundreds of thousands of dollars by pretending to have worked in this profession, and was eventually found out when others checked his work that was suspiciously free of errors. People working in this profession in the mid-20th century constructed temporary steel towers named after Jasper Bilby. A project carried out by people in this profession began with the Seven Ranges of eastern Ohio; that project applied a new system that replaced the traditional (*) metes and bounds method. A region called The Wedge was a relic of an expedition of two men in this profession that resolved a border dispute between Pennsylvania and Maryland. For 10 points, identify this best-known profession of Charles Mason and Jeremiah Dixon.

A newspaper editor in this city published a hoax story with a date three months in the future about a Russian cruiser called the Kaskowski that landed marines to extort gold from the local authorities. A decade later, another Russian scare in this city led to the construction of fortifications at Bastion Point and North Head. This city has been the main benefactor of the “drift to the north” trend of internal migration away from cities built during the (*) Otago Gold Rush. This city was the northern terminus of the Great Southern Road built during the invasion of the Waikato region, the stronghold of resistance to this city’s government. This city was built after Āpihai Te Kawau gifted the land around Waitematā Harbour to William Hobson after signing the Treaty of Waitangi. For 10 points, name this city in New Zealand, which was its capital for 25 years before Wellington and has long been the country’s most populous city.
